annotations.observations: During the performance Niyazi Sayin uses a mansur ney, which also implies the ahenk (transposiiton). The first two works have their karar (tonic) note as rast (G4). Until the end of Pesendide Sazsemaisi the tonic is performed approximately at 403 Hz.

annotations.observations: During the performance Niyazi Sayin uses a mansur ney, which also implies the ahenk (transposiiton). The first two works have their karar (tonic) note as rast (G4). Until the end of Pesendide Sazsemaisi the tonic is performed approximately at 403 Hz.

annotations.observations: During the performance Niyazi Sayin uses a mansur ney, which also implies the ahenk (transposiiton). The tonic of the Acemaşiran makam is the acemaşiran note (F4). The tonic shifts to 362 Hz within the performance of 3rd Taksim and stays the same throughout the performance of Acemaşiran Peşrev.

annotations.observations: The musicians start playing (in Isfahan Peşrev) the tonic approximately at 175Hz.

annotations.citation: Atlı, H. S., Bozkurt, B., Şentürk, S. (2015). A Method for Tonic Frequency Identification of Turkish Makam Music Recordings. In Proceedings of 5th International Workshop on Folk Music Analysis (FMA 2015), pages 119–122, Paris, France.
annotations.observations: The musicians start playing (in Isfahan Peşrev) the tonic approximately at 175Hz.

annotations.citation: Şentürk, S. (2016). Computational Analysis of Audio Recordings and Music Scores for the Description and Discovery of Ottoman-Turkish Makam Music. PhD thesis, Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona, Spain.
annotations.observations: At the 245th second mark, the virtuosos somehow lose their coordination and the melodic intervals are mixed. The tonic played at the conclusion (e.g. the karar note) of the first performance (Isfahan Peşrev) is around 185 Hz.

annotations.citation: Şentürk, S. (2016). Computational Analysis of Audio Recordings and Music Scores for the Description and Discovery of Ottoman-Turkish Makam Music. PhD thesis, Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona, Spain.
annotations.observations: Isfahan Sazsemaisi has a relatively stable tonic frequency at around 169Hz. Note that the historical recordings tend to have local pitch shifts which makes it hard to identify a precise or correct tonic frequency.
